poem:
Title: "Upon Viewing Gosling"

No grandeur, 
just regularity, 
a beard, a mansion,
restoring. 

Love, coerced into stillness,
you're not handsome, you're not cool,
declares Cassavetes.

But in the plain,
a deranged romance blooms,
a war veteran stunned into the page, 
a doe-eyed memoir
neatly penciled by Sparks.

In essence,
we all are Noah,
quiet, heartfelt,
the Notebook unending.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Ryan Gosling movies – ranked! 16. The Notebook (2004) Even The Notebook’s writer, Nicholas Sparks, knew that there wasn’t much to Noah, the romantically deranged, mansion-restoring, beard-growing war veteran in this insipid tearjerker. “It’s a guy who falls in love and then he just kinda does nothing,” he admitted. But director Nick Cassavetes had sound reasons for choosing Ryan Gosling. “You’re not handsome, you’re not cool, you’re just a regular guy who looks a bit". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
